conclusion: Determine if Car A's acceleration decreases and Car B's acceleration increases by analyzing velocity-time graphs.
The horizontal axis represents time (t) and the vertical axis represents velocity (v). The graph shows two curves for Car A and Car B.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, given by a(t) = dv/dt.
On a velocity-time graph, the slope of the tangent line at any point gives the instantaneous acceleration.
Car A's velocity increases over time.
The slope of the tangent line to Car A's curve is positive but decreasing, indicating decreasing acceleration.
Car B's velocity also increases over time.
The slope of the tangent line to Car B's curve is more pronounced, indicating increasing acceleration.
For Car A, the slope of the tangent line is decreasing, implying that its acceleration is decreasing.
For Car B, the slope of the tangent line is increasing, implying that its acceleration is increasing.
The magnitude of the acceleration of Car A gradually decreases, while the magnitude of the acceleration of Car B gradually increases.
